poem:
**Pop-up Democracy**  

In lines outside art—  
silent, student feet—  
a whisper of ballots  
in hands not far  
from textbooks.  

The pop-up pulse  
of voices, carried  
on crisp autumn air,  
threads the lawn like  
a quiet tapestry.  

Here, choice unfolds,  
folding space into  
an active, breathing  
summer-leaf democracy.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "US students rally college voters on campus: ‘We brought the polls to them’ College students formed a steady line outside a campus art museum to vote early on Tuesday at a pop-up polling place at the University of Minnesota. The one-day site, enabled by new state laws that allow for pop-up early voting, helps populations like student voters, who may not have access to transportation to get off campus, easily access the polls. “We brought". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
